courseTitle: Aseptic Technique and Use of Media

pageData.titleName2: Aseptic Technique and Use of Media

pageData.text: In this investigation, students will learn <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> laboratory practices for studying microorganisms. Students will demonstrate the proper use of aseptic technique by reactivating a lyophilized bacterial culture and then <button class='glossary-text'>subculturing</button> it in broth and on agar without the introduction of contaminants. Correct aseptic technique is essential for the success of subsequent experiments.

text: Explain and apply the <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> practices used for microbiology experiments.
Identify potential sources of contamination.
Apply techniques used for establishing microbial growth with liquid and solid <button class='glossary-text'>media</button>.

pageData.text: Nosocomial infections, also called hospital-acquired infections, are a huge risk to patients in hospitals. Though the numbers vary by area and hospital, some estimates say that about 1 in 10 patients in the hospital acquire an infection during their stay1. While some of these infections are mild like colds, some like methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), can be deadly. These infections can be spread from one patient to another from contact with equipment or from health care workers moving from patient to patient. Sterilization, disinfecting and technique are all important tools to help reduce the risk of infection inside the hospital. When healthcare workers perform procedures, be they major surgeries or routine tasks, they must practice aseptic technique to minimize infections. This includes disinfecting surfaces and the patient’s skin, treating all materials that they suspect have encountered a nonsterile surface as contaminated, and using checklists to make sure that no important infection control steps are missed. Hospitals also have protocols for how often to disinfect surfaces and how to sterilize equipment between patients. When followed carefully, these procedures can go a long way toward preventing nosocomial infections and keeping patients safe.
1Inweregbu, K., Dave, J., & Pittard, A. (2005). Nosocomial infections. Continuing Education in Anaesthesia Critical Care & Pain, 5(1), 14–17. https://doi.org/10.1093/bjaceaccp/mki006

pageData.desc: Healthcare workers performing surgery using aseptic technique.
pageData.altText: Healthcare workers performing surgery using aseptic technique.

pageData.text: The prevalence of microbes and their spores in the environment makes it important to maintain <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> (contamination-free) laboratory conditions. Proper aseptic technique minimizes the possibility of introducing contamination. The consistent use of aseptic technique prevents microbial cultures from becoming <button class='glossary-text'>contaminated</button> (inhabited by unwanted microbes). Contaminants such as unwanted bacterial and fungal spores may be introduced into the experiment by laboratory personnel, solutions, work surfaces, air, or many other sources. Contamination may affect a single tube or plate (Figure 1), or be so widespread that it compromises or ruins the entire experiment. Aseptic technique must be used to prevent contamination in all stages of a microbiology experiment.

Aseptic technique protects microbial cultures and individuals working in the microbiology laboratory. Although not all microbes are harmful to humans, some may cause infection and disease. Aseptic technique prevents those working with cultures from coming into contact with potentially harmful microbes.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A contaminated agar plate on whose surface are many different shapes and colors of microbial growth.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A contaminated agar plate on whose surface are many different shapes and colors of microbial growth.

pageData.text: Materials used to support microbial growth are called <button class='glossary-text'>media</button>. A medium may be liquid, such as nutrient broth, or solid, such as nutrient agar. A solid medium may come in a culture tube, such as an agar slant, or in a Petri dish (agar plate). Whatever the state of the medium, it contains nutrients and moisture to support the growth of microbes. To maintain <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> conditions, everything that comes in direct contact with a living culture—media, tools, containers, etc.—must be <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> (completely free of living microbes). Glassware and culture media (broth and agar) are sterilized, typically by autoclaving (treatment with pressurized steam). Disposable plastic items, such as Petri dishes, are normally sterilized by the manufacturer, typically using radiation.

Items that do not come into direct contact with cultures do not need to be sterilized, but they do need to be , meaning that the number of living microbes—particularly those potentially hazardous to humans—has been greatly reduced by application of a chemical or chemical mixture. For example, before and after an experiment, laboratory surfaces should be wiped down with a surface disinfectant such as a 10% solution of chlorine bleach in water.

Laboratory personnel should always wash their hands before beginning a procedure. Washing hands thoroughly with soap and warm water reduces the number of microbes on the skin. Handwashing neither sterilizes the skin, nor uses a harsh disinfectant; thus, some microbes will remain behind. For this reason, it is important to use gloves after washing and drying hands, and avoid contact with items that have not been sterilized or disinfected. Gloves provide protection against microbes if cultures are spilled. However, the warm, moist environment inside gloves encourages growth of microbes remaining on the skin. Therefore, hands should also be thoroughly washed after removing and discarding gloves.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements best describes aseptic laboratory conditions?

options.text: The laboratory is contamination-free.
The laboratory is free of unwanted bacterial spores.
The laboratory is occupied by a single researcher.
The laboratory does not culture any potentially harmful microbes.
The laboratory is kept at 25° C.

pageData.question: When should aseptic technique be used in an experiment?

options.text: in all stages
as a last resort
after a pure culture is obtained
before a pure culture is obtained
before hands are washed

pageData.text: technique is critical in maintaining a , in which microbes are genetically identical to one another and free of other species or strains. In this investigation, you will keep a pure culture of a specific bacterium free of contamination, while propagating it through a process known as . A subculture is produced when a small amount of microbes is taken from an original pure culture and (introduced) into a fresh, medium. The microbes used to inoculate a medium are referred to as the . When you inoculate a previously sterile medium, some or all of the following indicators of microbial growth should appear during the incubation process:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Turbidity</button> (uniform cloudiness) in the broth (Figure 2). Sometimes a slight bacterial film develops on the surface and disperses into the broth when the culture is agitated.
Floating or suspended particulate matter in the broth that was not present prior to incubation.
Solid precipitate at the bottom of the broth that was not present prior to incubation.
The appearance of anything on agar that was not present prior to inoculation.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Three culture tubes containing solutions with varying degrees of cloudiness.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Three culture tubes containing solutions with varying degrees of cloudiness.

pageData.text: Mastery of <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> technique and <button class='glossary-text'>subculturing</button> is important for the success of micro-biological experiments. The best way to approach all microbiological investigations is to take one’s time and to work carefully. If at any point you suspect that you may have disrupted aseptic conditions, take corrective measures. For instance, if your <button class='glossary-text'>disinfected</button> benchtop is touched by a <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> inoculating loop, the loop is no longer considered sterile and should be discarded. If you must handle something that has not been disinfected, remove your gloves, perform the task, and then put on fresh gloves. Breaking aseptic technique without taking corrective measures can result in wasted time and resources, potential microbial infection, and a ruined experiment.

pageData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be an indicator of microbial growth on inoculated media?

options.text: condensation appears inside the plate lid of agar media
liquid nutrient broth appears cloudy
floating particles appear in liquid nutrient broth
a solid precipitate appears at the bottom of a nutrient broth tube
fuzzy growth appears on the surface of agar media

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When you inoculate a previously sterile medium, microbial growth can appear as turbidity (cloudiness), floating or suspended particulate matter, a solid precipitate at the bottom of the broth, or the appearance of anything new on the surface of agar.

pageData.question: If you must handle something that has not been disinfected while in the middle of an experiment, what should you do?

options.text: Discard your gloves, perform the task, then put on fresh gloves.
Perform the task, then wash your gloves.
Perform the task, then return to the experiment.
Perform the task, then start the experiment over.
Remove your gloves, perform the task, then put on the same gloves.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If you must handle something that has not been disinfected while in the middle of an experiment, discard your gloves, perform the task, then put on fresh gloves.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A subculture is produced when a small amount of microbes is taken from an original pure culture and inoculated (introduced) into a fresh, sterile medium. The microbes used to inoculate a medium are referred to as the inoculum. Mastery of aseptic technique and subculturing is important for the success of microbiological experiments. The best way to approach all microbiological investigations is to take one’s time and to work carefully. If at any point you suspect that you may have disrupted aseptic conditions, take corrective measures. For instance, if your disinfected benchtop is touched by a sterile inoculating loop, the loop is no longer considered sterile and should be discarded. Breaking aseptic technique without taking corrective measures can result in wasted time and resources, potential microbial infection, and a ruined experiment.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before the investigation, prepare the culture vials. Disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and label your tubes. In activity 1, reactivate a lyophilized culture and incubate it for 24-72 hours. Before proceeding to activity 2, watch the technique videos, disinfect your work surface and prepare your disposal jar. Then, prepare the cultures, sterile broth tubes, slants and plates. In activity 2, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the sterile broth tube with the loop and incubate the tube.  Next, observe microbial growth. In activity 3, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the slant with the loop using the fishtail technique. Next, incubate the slant and observe microbial growth. In activity 4, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the plate with the loop. Finally, incubate the plate and observe microbial growth.

In activity 2, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the sterile broth tube with the loop and incubate the tube.  Next, observe microbial growth. In activity 3, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the slant with the loop using the fishtail technique. Next, incubate the slant and observe microbial growth. In activity 4, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the plate with the loop. Finally, incubate the plate and observe microbial growth.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Refer to your instructions and videos on safe practices in the microbiology laboratory before beginning this investigation.
Isopropyl alcohol is flammable. Keep containers of isopropyl alcohol away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity.
Put on PPE and disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation.

After completing your work, disinfect and discard any used inoculating tools and unneeded cultures. Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT true about media used in microbiology?

options.text: Media includes dye to visualize microbial growth.
Media contain nutrients and moisture to support microbial growth.
Media can be liquid nutrient broth.
Media can be solid agar slants.
Media must be sterile before it is inoculated with microbes.

assestmentData.question: What is the difference between sterilization and disinfection?

options.text: Sterilization kills all the microbes; disinfection greatly reduces microbe numbers.
Sterilization greatly reduces microbe numbers; disinfection kills all microbes.
Sterilization is cleaning by handwashing; disinfection is cleaning by strong chemicals or radiation.
Sterilization is killing microbes on a surface; disinfection is killing microbes on living tissue.
Sterilization and disinfection mean the same thing.

assestmentData.question: Which statement about gloves and handwashing is NOT correct?

options.text: Handwashing is not necessary after removing and discarding gloves.
Hands should be washed before beginning a procedure.
Gloves provide protection against microbes if cultures are spilled.
Even while wearing gloves, one should avoid contact with items that have not been sterilized or disinfected.
Handwashing does not remove all microbes from the skin of the hands.

assestmentData.question: If you suspect that you have touched the benchtop with a sterile inoculation loop, what should you do?

options.text: Assume the loop is not sterile and discard it.
Assume the loop is sterile and continue using it.
Begin the entire experiment over.
Disinfect the suspected loop with bleach and continue using it.
Soak the loop in isopropyl alcohol for 2 minutes and continue using it.

assestmentData.question: This investigation requires the use of 70% isopropyl alcohol to sterilize equipment. Which of the following items should be kept away from the alcohol container during your experiments?

options.text: the lit candle
any sterilized inoculating loops
the culture tube rack, if it is full
any inoculated tryptic soy agar slants
the empty lyophilized bacteria vials

assestmentData.question: A 10% bleach solution will be created and used to disinfect your work surfaces during the investigation. Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Which of the following steps should you take if bleach comes in contact with your skin or eyes?

options.text: Rinse the affected area in the shower.
Wipe the affected area with a dry paper towel.
Rinse the affected area with a baking soda solution.
Apply an ice pack to the affected area.
Allow the affected area to air dry and call poison control.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?

options.text: a large plastic container for lab-use only
a blacklight
a bacterial sample collected from a household surface
dish towels
a volunteer

In Activity 1, you will reactivate a lyophilized culture of bacteria by adding the culture to a tryptic soy broth tube using <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> technique. Once the culture has incubated, you will use it in Activities 2, 3 and 4.
Read all instructions carefully before you start working.
Watch the following videos before proceeding with Activity 1:
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE (gloves, protective eyewear, and lab apron or lab coat).

Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with surface disinfectant by applying the 10% bleach solution with a paper towel, allowing all treated surfaces to remain damp for approximately 2 minutes, and then wiping away any remaining solution with a dry paper towel.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Retrieve a tryptic soy broth tube from storage.
As a general rule, allow that have been stored in the refrigerator to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature prior to inoculation.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the tube of tryptic soy broth with the name of the organism and the date.
Using a match or lighter, light your liquid paraffin candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

pages.title: Aseptic Reactivation of a Lyophilized Culture
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Aseptic Reactivation of a Lyophilized Culture (16 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: These instructions are very similar to the reactivation instructions that came with your culture. However, they include additional details to assist the student who is learning the basics of technique.

pageData.text: Carefully remove the metal band from the lyophilized culture vial by lifting the metal circle in the center and then pulling to one side. The metal band may be discarded in the household garbage.
Remove the <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> plastic pipette from its wrapping. Do not set the pipette down; instead, hold it in your dominant hand.

Using the pinky finger of your dominant hand (or your pinky and ring fingers), remove the cap from the tube of tryptic soy broth. Do not set the cap down. Hold it with your pinky while the tube is open.

Tryptic soy broth will be used to rehydrate the lyophilized culture. Run the mouth of the open tube of tryptic soy broth two or three times through the candle flame. This step is called flaming the mouth of the culture tube.
Holding the tube at an angle, insert the pipette tip to obtain 1 mL of tryptic soy broth.
Flame the mouth of the culture tube and replace the cap. Set the tube aside in the rack.
Using your non-dominant hand, remove the cap from the lyophilized culture vial.
Dispense the contents of the pipette onto the lyophilized culture pellet. Replace the rubber stopper and wait for about 30 seconds.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the rubber stopper and mix the culture gently by slowly squeezing and releasing the pipette bulb several times and stirring with the tip. Try to avoid introducing excessive air bubbles into the culture.
Remove the cap from the tube of tryptic soy broth (again, do not set the cap down), and flame the mouth of the tube.
Use the pipette to transfer the dissolved culture from the vial to the tube of tryptic soy broth.

Flame the mouth of the tube and replace the cap. Screw the cap to the point of finger-tightness, then backwards about one-quarter of a turn. This will leave the cap just loose enough that air (but not contaminants) can enter the tube.
Place the pipette in the disposal jar.

After rehydration, the next step in reactivation of a lyophilized culture is incubation. Set the tube in the rack and allow it to incubate for 24–72 hours. At or near optimal temperature, which is printed on the lyophilized culture vial, the culture will be completely reactivated within 24–48 hours, but at cooler temperatures, more time is usually required.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text:
Note: Both Micrococcus luteus and Staphylococcus epidermidis are non-motile and their growth will be along the bottom of the tube. You can gently swirl the tube to see if the growth at bottom of the tube moves. If you see a good swirl of growth at the bottom then your culture should be ready to proceed to the next step.
The Escherichia coli and Serratia marcescens are both motile and their growth should be throughout the culture medium so they will appear turbid though they will also have more growth along the bottom of the tube.
Wait until your culture is turbid () before proceeding to Activity 2. Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to become significantly turbid.
Extinguish the candle.
Follow the Disposal and Cleanup guidelines at the end of this investigation to dispose of the used items. Disinfect your work area as directed.
In Activity 2, you will use <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> technique to transfer bacteria from the Activity 1 culture to a new broth tube using an inoculation loop.

typeAfter.desc: Opening and Closing a Sleeve of Plates
Transfer from Broth to Slant (Fishtail Inoculation of an Agar Slant)

pageData.text: View the following videos before proceeding with the activity.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.
Prepare your disposal jar by adding 70% isopropyl alcohol to the small plastic container.
Retrieve one tryptic soy broth tube, one tryptic soy agar slant, and one tryptic soy agar plate. Place the tubes in the rack on the <button class='glossary-text'>disinfected</button> work surface.
Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the tubes with the name of the organism with which you will inoculate them and the date.
Label the outside of the bottom of the plate (the half with the agar in it) with the name of the organism and the date.
Light your liquid paraffin candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

pages.title: Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Broth
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Broth (11 steps)

pageData.text: Completely close the cap of the reactivated culture and mix the contents by tapping the tube gently or rolling it between your palms.

Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid ().
Remove a <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> inoculating loop from its packaging. Do not set the loop down. Hold it in your dominant hand.
Remove the cap from the reactivated culture. Remember: do not set the cap down. Hold it with the pinky of your dominant hand while holding the tube in your non-dominant hand.
Flame the mouth of the tube.
Holding the tube at an angle, insert the inoculating loop to obtain a loop of liquid broth, then withdraw the loop. Do not set the loop down.
Flame the mouth of the tube and replace the cap. Set the tube aside in the rack.
Remove the cap from the fresh tryptic soy broth tube. Do not set the cap down.
Flame the open mouth of the tube. While holding the tube at an angle, insert the inoculating loop and swish it about gently.
Remove the loop, flame the mouth of the tube, and replace the cap.
Set the newly-<button class='glossary-text'>inoculated</button> tube in the rack for incubation. Leave its cap slightly loose.
Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar.

In Activity 3, you will use <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> technique to transfer bacteria from the Activity 1 culture to a slant tube using an inoculation loop and the fishtail inoculation technique.

typeAfter.desc: Opening and Closing a Sleeve of Plates
Transfer from Broth to Slant (Fishtail Inoculation of an Agar Slant)

pageData.text: View the following videos before proceeding with the activity.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.
Prepare your disposal jar by adding 70% isopropyl alcohol to the small plastic container.
Retrieve one nutrient broth tube, one tryptic soy agar slant, and one nutrient agar plate. Place the tubes in the rack on the <button class='glossary-text'>disinfected</button> work surface.
Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the tubes with the name of the organism with which you will inoculate them and the date.
Label the outside of the bottom of the plate (the half with the agar in it) with the name of the organism and the date.
Light your liquid paraffin candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

pages.title: Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Slant
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Slant (10 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid ().

pageData.text: Remove a <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> inoculating loop from its packaging. Do not set the loop down. Hold it in your dominant hand.
Remove the cap from the reactivated culture. Remember: do not set the cap down. Hold it with the pinky of your dominant hand while holding the tube in your non-dominant hand.
Flame the mouth of the tube.
Holding the tube at an angle, insert the inoculating loop to obtain a loop of liquid broth then withdraw the loop. Do not set the loop down.
Flame the mouth of the tube and replace the cap. Set the tube aside in the rack.
Remove the cap from the tryptic soy agar slant. Do not set the cap down.

Flame the open mouth of the tube. While holding the tube at an angle, insert the inoculating loop and touch it to the bottom of the slant. Do not gouge the loop into the agar. Draw the loop back out of the tube, dragging it from side to side across the surface of the agar. This is known as a “fishtail” inoculation because the way the loop is moved side-to-side is reminiscent of the tail movements of a swimming fish.
Remove the loop, flame the mouth of the tube, and replace the cap.
Set the newly-<button class='glossary-text'>inoculated</button> tube in the rack for incubation. Leave its cap slightly loose.
Place the inoculating loop in the disposal jar.
In Activity 4, you will use <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic</button> technique to transfer bacteria from the Activity 1 culture to an agar plate using an inoculation loop.

typeAfter.desc: Opening and Closing a Sleeve of Plates
Transfer from Broth to Slant (Fishtail Inoculation of an Agar Slant)

pageData.text: View the following videos before proceeding with the activity.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. Dry your hands, and then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.
Prepare your disposal jar by adding 70% isopropyl alcohol to the small plastic container.
Retrieve one nutrient broth tube, one tryptic soy agar slant, and one nutrient agar plate. Place the tubes in the rack on the <button class='glossary-text'>disinfected</button> work surface.
Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the tubes with the name of the organism with which you will inoculate them and the date.
Label the outside of the bottom of the plate (the half with the agar in it) with the name of the organism and the date.
Light your liquid paraffin candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

pages.title: Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Plate
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Aseptic Transfer from Broth Culture to Plate (7 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: It is important that all the cells are in suspension. If there is a mass of cells (sediment) at the bottom of the tube, it may be necessary to gently invert the tube to ensure the cells are in suspension. Once your cells are in suspension, your culture should appear turbid ().

pageData.text: Remove the cap of the reactivated culture, and flame the mouth of the tube.
Obtain a loop of broth. Flame the mouth of the tube and replace the cap.
Lift the lid of the Petri dish slightly. Do not remove the lid completely, and do not set it aside. Use the lid as a shield to protect the agar from contamination by airborne microbes.

Touch the loop gently to the surface of the agar. Drag it over the surface of the agar in a back-and-forth, zigzag fashion. Take care not to gouge the agar. Close the lid immediately after you have <button class='glossary-text'>inoculated</button> the plate.
Place the loop in the disposal jar.
Invert the plate (turn it upside-down) for incubation.
Follow the Disposal and Cleanup guidelines at the end of this investigation to dispose of the used materials. Disinfect your work area.

Incubate all three cultures. After approximately 48 hours of incubation, examine your cultures. Do not remove the caps of your tubes or the lid of the Petri dish during any observation, because this may result in contamination.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Take pictures of your cultures. For photographs of microbial cultures, avoid use of the flash, which will simply be reflected off the glass or plastic culture container. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your workspace.
Observe and photograph the cultures again after approximately 72 hours of incubation.Your should exhibit increasing amounts of microbial growth throughout the incubation period.
Note: Micrococcus luteus is fastidious and grows slowly at suboptimal conditions. If incubating at cooler temperatures, it may take five days or more for some strains to show significant growth.

To dispose of used inoculating tools (loops, pipettes, etc.), let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes, then pour the alcohol down the drain while the faucet is running, and discard the materials in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text:
Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the
alcohol.
Note: Keep your cultures unless otherwise directed by your instructor. They may be used for future investigations.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of the lyophilized culture vial and rubber stopper, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a plastic container with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution. If your instructor directs you to dispose of any items, you may use this same bleach bath to disinfect them as well. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: Place the <button class='glossary-text'>disinfected</button> tubes and plates in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage. Be sure to wash your hands after removing your gloves.

After working with microbes, be sure to disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution. To remove bleach residue, clean the disinfected area with soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: Do you think there were any deficiencies in your aseptic technique, and if so, can you identify them? Explain your answer. If there were no deficiencies in your aseptic technique, identify at least one potential way through which contamination could occur while working with cultures.
Which was most challenging for you in terms of aseptic technique: transfer from broth to broth, broth to slant, or broth to plate? Explain your answer.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A contaminated agar plate on whose surface are many different shapes and colors of microbial growth.
Figure 2: Three culture tubes containing solutions with varying degrees of cloudiness.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before the investigation, prepare the culture vials. Disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and label your tubes. In activity 1, reactivate a lyophilized culture and incubate it for 24-72 hours. Before proceeding to activity 2, watch the technique videos, disinfect your work surface and prepare your disposal jar. Then, prepare the cultures, sterile broth tubes, slants and plates. In activity 2, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the sterile broth tube with the loop and incubate the tube.  Next, observe microbial growth. In activity 3, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the slant with the loop using the fishtail technique. Next, incubate the slant and observe microbial growth. In activity 4, inoculate the loop in the culture. Then, inoculate the plate with the loop. Finally, incubate the plate and observe microbial growth.

pageData.content: Opening and Closing a Sleeve of Plates
Transfer from Broth to Slant (Fishtail Inoculation of an Agar Slant)

data.title: Disinfected
data.content: Cleaned with a chemical such that the number of microbes is reduced

data.title: Inoculated
data.content: Introduced with microbes (referring to a culture medium)

data.title: Inoculum
data.content: The microbes used to inoculate a medium

data.title: Media
data.content: Substances used to support microbial growth; singular, medium

data.title: Pure culture
data.content: A sample of genetically-identical microbes that is free of other species or strains

data.title: Subculturing
data.content: Taking a small amount of microbes from an original pure culture and inoculating it in fresh sterile media

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Cloudiness in a solution that is a result of small particles in suspension
